discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Layer order in the Selection pane

To ensure that Sales Summary renders on top of Shape1, you need to adjust their layer order in the Selection pane. Power BI renders visuals based on the layer order in the Selection pane, with the topmost visual being rendered last and therefore appearing on top of other visuals.

To adjust the layer order, you can select the visuals in the Selection pane and drag them up or down to change their position in the layer order. In this case, you would want to select Sales Summary and drag it above Shape1 in the layer order to ensure it is rendered on top.

To display the bar chart on Dashboard1, you need to pin the new Sales by month bar chart to Dashboard1.

Build a case! the solution is:
1. create a page, then in Page Information, give it a meaningful name(MY_TOOLTIP)
2. Page Information > Allow use as tooltip : ON
3. you want your tooltip to show corresponding information to what you are data hovering on your main page. So you need to apply filter to your tooltip so it can show the corresponding data. This is done in Visualizations > tooltip > Drag tooltip values here --> this will show the tooltip when you hover the row/column/element where you want you custom tooltip to appear
4. Your main report and control that you want to give it a custom tooltip: click your control: visualizations > Format Visual > General > Options > Page --> select your tooltip page (MY_TOOLTIP).
So, what you dot is:
create a custom page with controls and allow it to be used as a tooltip
Apply filters on that page to be sync'd with what you will select
In your main page, select the control and tell it it will use your custom tooltip page.
--> E D A (or A D E)
